unnormalised: Someone asked me about my most intense experience working in the ER. It definitely takes me back to when I was doing my residency at AIIMS, Delhi. It was around 10:30 PM, and things were relatively calm for a change, when suddenly, ambulances started pouring in. Apparently, a major pile-up happened on NH8, just outside Gurgaon.
normalised: Someone asked me about my most intense experience working in the E-R. It definitely takes me back to when I was doing my residency at A-I-I-M-S, Delhi. It was around ten thirty P-M, and things were relatively calm for a change, when suddenly, ambulances started pouring in. Apparently, a major pile-up happened on N-H eight, just outside Gurgaon.

unnormalised: The first patient, a young woman, maybe 22 yrs old, was in critical condition, GCS of 8. She had severe head trauma, and Dr. Sharma suspected a subdural hematoma immediately. We rushed her for a CT scan - reports came back confirming our fears. Meanwhile, we had another patient, an elderly gentleman, who was complaining of severe chest pain. His ECG showed ST elevation – classic signs of an MI. We gave him aspirin 300mg stat and prepped him for thrombolysis.
normalised: The first patient, a young woman, maybe twenty two years old, was in critical condition, G-C-S of eight. She had severe head trauma, and Doctor Sharma suspected a subdural hematoma immediately. We rushed her for a C-T scan - reports came back confirming our fears. Meanwhile, we had another patient, an elderly gentleman, who was complaining of severe chest pain. His E-C-G showed S-T elevation – classic signs of an M-I. We gave him aspirin three hundred milligram stat and prepped him for thrombolysis.

unnormalised: Then came a little boy, probably around 6 yrs old, accompanied by his distraught mother. He had a fractured femur, screaming in pain. We gave him morphine 5mg IV for pain relief. That night felt like a blur, a constant stream of patients with varying degrees of trauma and emergencies. I remember checking my watch at 4:00 AM; it felt like only an hour had passed.
normalised: Then came a little boy, probably around six years old, accompanied by his distraught mother. He had a fractured femur, screaming in pain. We gave him morphine five milligram I-V for pain relief. That night felt like a blur, a constant stream of patients with varying degrees of trauma and emergencies. I remember checking my watch at four A-M; it felt like only an hour had passed.

unnormalised: By the time the sun rose, we had managed to stabilize most of the patients, but the exhaustion was overwhelming. That night taught me the true meaning of emergency medicine – being prepared for anything, staying calm under pressure, and making split-second decisions that could mean the difference between life and death. It’s a demanding field, but incredibly rewarding.
